starting_inventory.description: Issue plate for officers of Rhaud's vanguard. The gold trim marks captain's rank.
Layered steel plates lined with northern wolf pelt. Worn by captains who've served the frontier.
Standard military greaves with reinforced knee plates.
A kite shield bearing the lion crest of Rhaud. Issued only to the kingdom's sworn defenders.
A well-balanced longsword forged for Rhaud's vanguard officers. The red gem in the pommel is a tradition — one for each generation of captains.
Navy wool cape clasped at the left shoulder. Identifies the wearer as an officer of the watch.
Wide leather belt with brass buckle and hip pouch. Built to carry a captain's essentials on campaign.
Blue wool cowl from the northern frontier. More sentimental than practical.

design_notes.power_level: Metz starts stronger than most RPG protagonists. His gear is tier 2-4, reflecting his rank. The player feels like a capable captain, not a village nobody. First upgrades come mid-Act I when Atikesh's forces start overwhelming standard military equipment.
design_notes.narrative_items: The Shield of Rhaud and Frontier Cowl are never replaced — they're identity items that stay with Metz throughout the game. The shield is his oath to the kingdom; the cowl is personal.
design_notes.visual_progression: Act I upgrades are lateral (steel → reinforced steel). The BIG visual change comes in Act II when mythril and enchanted items enter the picture, shifting the palette from blue-grey/navy to pale blue/silver/gold.
